items.title: Physicists 3D-printed a Christmas tree of ice
items.summary: New method uses no freezing technology or refrigeration equipmentâ€”just water and a vacuum.
items.body: Physicists at the University of Amsterdam came up with a really cool bit of Christmas decor: a miniature 3D-printed Christmas tree, a mere 8 centimeters tall, made of ice, without any refrigeration equipment or other freezing technology, and at minimal cost. The secret is evaporative cooling, according to a preprint posted to the physics arXiv. Evaporative cooling is a well-known phenomenon; mammals use it to regulate body temperature. You can see it in your morning cup of hot coffee: the hotter atoms rise to the top of the magnetic trap and â€œjump outâ€ as steam. It also plays a role (along with shock wave dynamics and various other factors) in the formation of â€œ wine tears. â€ Itâ€™s a key step in creating Bose-Einstein condensates. And evaporative cooling is also the main culprit behind the infamous â€œstallâ€ that so frequently plagues aspiring BBQ pit masters eager to make a successful pork butt. The meat sweats as it cooks, releasing the moisture within, and that moisture evaporates and cools the meat, effectively canceling out the heat from the BBQ. Thatâ€™s why a growing number of competitive pit masters wrap their meat in tinfoil after the first few hours (usually when the internalâ€¦

items.title: OpenAIâ€™s new ChatGPT image generator makes faking photos easy
items.summary: New GPT Image 1.5 allows more detailed conversational image editing, for better or worse.
items.body: For most of photographyâ€™s roughly 200-year history, altering a photo convincingly required either a darkroom, some Photoshop expertise, or, at minimum, a steady hand with scissors and glue. On Tuesday, OpenAI released a tool that reduces the process to typing a sentence. Itâ€™s not the first company to do so. While OpenAI had a conversational image-editing model in the works since GPT-4o in 2024, Google beat OpenAI to market in March with a public prototype, then refined it to a popular model called Nano Banana image model (and Nano Banana Pro ). The enthusiastic response to Googleâ€™s image-editing model in the AI community got OpenAIâ€™s attention . OpenAIâ€™s new GPT Image 1.5 is an AI image synthesis model that reportedly generates images up to four times faster than its predecessor and costs about 20 percent less through the API. The model rolled out to all ChatGPT users on Tuesday and represents another step toward making photorealistic image manipulation a casual process that requires no particular visual skills. Read full article Comments

items.title: Man sues cops who jailed him for 37 days for trolling a Charlie Kirk vigil
items.summary: Cops may be fined for jailing a man over his Facebook posts.
items.body: Larry Bushart, a man who was jailed for 37 days for reposting a Trump meme , has now sued the cops who allegedly schemed to keep him imprisoned for as long as possible simply because they disagreed with his point of view. Bushart is a former cop who lost his post-retirement job after a seemingly vengeful sheriff jailed him for trolling a Charlie Kirk vigil post in a Facebook group. Upset that Kirkâ€™s death commanded more attention than other victims of gun violence, Bushart posted a string of memes, among which was an image of Trump with an actual quote saying â€œWe have to get over itâ€ about a 2024 school shooting. Perry County sheriff Nick Weems has since acknowledged that he â€œknewâ€ that the meme referenced a prior school shooting. However, the entire time that Bushart was detained, Weems maintained that Bushartâ€™s post incited â€œmass hysteriaâ€ from parents concerned that he was threatening violence at a local high school. Painting Bushart as indifferent to the supposed hysteria, Weems justified his arrest, as well as the $2 million bond ensuring Bushart couldnâ€™t afford bail and remained behind bars. Read full article Comments

items.title: FCC chair scrubs website after learning it called FCC an â€œindependent agencyâ€
items.summary: Meanwhile, Ted Cruz wants to restrict FCC's power to intimidate broadcasters.
items.body: Federal Communications Commission Chairman Brendan Carr today faced blistering criticism in a Senate hearing for his September threats to revoke ABC station licenses over comments made by Jimmy Kimmel. While Democrats provided nearly all the criticism, Sen. Ted Cruz (R-Texas) said that Congress should act to restrict the FCCâ€™s power to intimidate news broadcasters. As an immediate result of todayâ€™s hearing , the FCC removed a statement from its website that said it is an independent agency. Carr, who has embraced President Trumpâ€™s declaration that independent agencies may no longer operate independently from the White House, apparently didnâ€™t realize that the website still called the FCC an independent agency. â€œYes or no, is the FCC an independent agency?â€ Sen. Ben Ray LujÃ¡n (D-N.M.) asked. Carr answered that the FCC is not independent, prompting LujÃ¡n to point to a statement on the FCC website calling the FCC â€œan independent US government agency overseen by Congress.â€ Read full article Comments

items.title: Donut Labâ€™s hub motor meets WATTâ€™s battery to create new EV skateboard
items.summary: A prototype of the EV platform will be shown off at CES next month.
items.body: One of the big stories of last yearâ€™s Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas was the debut of Donut Labâ€™s diminutive but powerful electric motors . When I spoke with Donut earlier this year, the company told me that it was looking at applications ranging from drones to large automotive motors, but also things like wind turbines and even washing machines. Now, almost a year later, we have our first look at an electric vehicle that uses the technology, thanks to a new collaboration between Donut Lab and WATT Electric Vehicle Company. WATT had previously developed the Passenger and Commercial EV Skateboard (PACES), a lightweight aluminum platform for low-volume EVs. Now, itâ€™s integrating Donutâ€™s motors, first with one for each rear wheel, although there will eventually be an all-wheel-drive variant, too. The small EV chassis is rather intriguingâ€”with the motors in the rear wheel hubs, the layout is even more space-efficient than a more conventional EV, which still needs to find a few cubic feet to package its drive unit(s). The two companies see plenty of potential for the platform, which they say could give rise to â€œmultiple vehicle configurations from beach buggies to high-performaâ€¦

items.title: Trump admin threatens to break up major climate research center
items.summary: Major research institution dismissed as a source of "climate alarmism."
items.body: On Tuesday, the head of the Office of Management and Budget, Russell Vought, announced that a major climate research center will be â€œbroken up.â€ The National Center for Atmospheric Research, or NCAR, is a significant contributor to research on the weather, climate, and other atmospheric phenomena. The move will be a crippling blow to climate research in the US and is being widely decried by scientists. Vought initially gave a statement regarding NCAR to USA Today and later confirmed the outletâ€™s reporting on social media. Calling it â€œone of the largest sources of climate alarmism in the country,â€ Vought also decried what he termed â€œwokeâ€ activities at NCAR. These appear to be fairly typical efforts made to attract underrepresented groups to the sciencesâ€”efforts that were uncontroversial prior to the current administration. NCAR is primarily based in a complex on the outskirts of Boulder, Colorado, and maintains a supercomputing center in Wyoming. Much of its funding comes from the National Science Foundation, but the day-to-day management is handled by the University Corporation for Atmospheric Research (UCAR), a nonprofit that represents 130 individual educational institutions. Iâ€¦

items.title: Google releases Gemini 3 Flash, promising improved intelligence and efficiency
items.summary: Google's Gemini 3 family is now complete with release of Gemini 3 Flash.
items.body: Google began its transition to Gemini 3 a few weeks ago with the launch of the Pro model , and the arrival of Gemini 3 Flash kicks it into high gear. The new, faster Gemini 3 model is coming to the Gemini app and search, and developers will be able to access it immediately via the Gemini API, Vertex AI, AI Studio, and Antigravity. Googleâ€™s bigger gen AI model is also picking up steam, with both Gemini 3 Pro and its image component (Nano Banana Pro) expanding in search. This may come as a shock, but Google says Gemini 3 Flash is faster and more capable than its previous base model. As usual, Google has a raft of benchmark numbers that show modest improvements for the new model. It bests the old 2.5 Flash in basic academic and reasoning tests like GPQA Diamond and MMMU Pro (where it even beats 3 Pro). It gets a larger boost in Humanityâ€™s Last Exam (HLE), which tests advanced domain-specific knowledge. Gemini 3 Flash has tripled the old modelsâ€™ score in HLE, landing at 33.7 percent without tool use. Thatâ€™s just a few points behind the Gemini 3 Pro model. Credit: Google Read full article Comments

items.title: Browser extensions with 8 million users collect extended AI conversations
items.summary: The extensions, available for Chromium browsers, harvest full AI conversations over months.
items.body: Browser extensions with more than 8 million installs are harvesting complete and extended conversations from usersâ€™ AI conversations and selling them for marketing purposes, according to data collected from the Google and Microsoft pages hosting them. Security firm Koi discovered the eight extensions, which as of late Tuesday night remained available in both Googleâ€™s and Microsoftâ€™s extension stores. Seven of them carry â€œFeaturedâ€ badges, which are endorsements meant to signal that the companies have determined the extensions meet their quality standards. The free extensions provide functions such as VPN routing to safeguard online privacy and ad blocking for ad-free browsing. All provide assurances that user data remains anonymous and isnâ€™t shared for purposes other than their described use. A gold mine for marketers and data brokers An examination of the extensionsâ€™ underlying code tells a much more complicated story. Each contains eight of what Koi calls â€œexecutorâ€ scripts, with each being unique for ChatGPT, Claude, Gemini, and five other leading AI chat platforms. The scripts are injected into webpages anytime the user visits one of these platforms. From there, the scripts ovâ€¦

items.title: Electric vehicles cause tension in the automotive aftermarket
items.summary: At SEMA, we heard Trump-like talking points but saw skateboard chassis, too.
items.body: After federal clean vehicle tax credits ended in September, the electric vehicle industry reached a crossroads. Well, technically, it has been there since Trump took office . This is a weird period in automotive history; A chunk of the industry is full-steam ahead with EV development, another is cutting back, and the consumer is left wondering what the electrification landscape will look like next year, let alone in three, during the next administration. But what about the automotive aftermarket? Typically, this corner benefits from whatever progress is made on the OEM frontâ€”have Trumpâ€™s policies expanded or contracted its EV technological development? I recently spent some time chatting with personnel of the Specialty Equipment Market Association (SEMA) at its yearly tradeshow in Las Vegas to find out. I also hit the bricks (or, rather, bright carpeting) of the massive show itself, seeking out some new, unique developments in the space that behoove EV techâ€™s inherent benefits. Above one of the showâ€™s several sprawling halls, I met with Mike Spagnola, SEMAâ€™s CEO, and Karen Bailey-Chapman, senior vice president, public and government affairs, to learn what the organizationâ€™s officiâ€¦

items.body: On Tuesday, X Corporation, formerly known as Twitter, sued â€œOperation Bluebird,â€ the new startup that is seeking to reclaim the allegedly abandoned Twitter trademark and relaunch a new social media network under that name. In its 43-page lawsuit , which was filed in federal court in Delaware, X Corporation alleges trademark infringement, adding that despite Bluebirdâ€™s â€œpurported plan, it cannot bring Twitter â€˜backâ€™â€”Twitter never left and continues to be exclusively owned by X Corp.â€ One of Bluebirdâ€™s leaders, Michael Peroff , told Ars in an email that Operation Bluebird was â€œfully expectingâ€ a lawsuit from X Corporation and that â€œwe planned for it.â€ Read full article Comments

items.summary: Trumpâ€™s AI â€œManhattan Projectâ€ will fail if DOGE cuts are kept, critics say.
items.body: By executive order last month, Donald Trump launched his so-called â€œGenesis Mission.â€ Described as a â€œhistoric national effortâ€ to â€œinvest in AI-enabled science to accelerate scientific advancement,â€ Trump claimed his mission would address key challenges to American energy dominance, innovation, and national security. This mission, Trump boasted, would be a game-changer to science akin to putting a man on the moon or firing the first nuclear weapons. By building â€œan integrated AI platformâ€ trained on â€œthe worldâ€™s largest collectionâ€ of federal scientific data sets, he promised, the government could set off cascades of scientific breakthroughs. items.title: Texas sues biggest TV makers, alleging smart TVs spy on users without consent
items.summary: Automated Content Recognition brings "mass surveillance" to homes, lawsuits say.
items.body: Texas Attorney General Ken Paxton sued five large TV manufacturers yesterday, alleging that their smart TVs spy on viewers without consent. Paxton sued Samsung, the longtime TV market share leader, along with LG, Sony, Hisense, and TCL. â€œThese companies have been unlawfully collecting personal data through Automated Content Recognition (â€˜ACRâ€™) technology,â€ Paxtonâ€™s office alleged in a press release that contains links to all five lawsuits. â€œACR in its simplest terms is an uninvited, invisible digital invader. This software can capture screenshots of a userâ€™s television display every 500 milliseconds, monitor viewing activity in real time, and transmit that information back to the company without the userâ€™s knowledge or consent. The companies then sell that consumer information to target ads across platforms for a profit. This technology puts usersâ€™ privacy and sensitive information, such as passwords, bank information, and other personal information at risk.â€ The lawsuits allege violations of the Texas Deceptive Trade Practices Act, seeking damages of up to $10,000 for each violation and up to $250,000 for each violation affecting people 65 years or older. Texas also wants restraiâ€¦

items.title: The $4.3 billion space telescope Trump tried to cancel is now complete
items.summary: "We're going to be making 3D movies of what is going on in the Milky Way galaxy."
items.body: A few weeks ago, technicians inside a cavernous clean room in Maryland made the final connection to complete assembly of NASAâ€™s Nancy Grace Roman Space Telescope. Parts of this new observatory, named for NASAâ€™s first chief astronomer, recently completed a spate of tests to ensure it can survive the shaking and intense sound of a rocket launch. Engineers placed the core of the telescope inside a thermal vacuum chamber, where it withstood the airless conditions and extreme temperature swings it will see in space. Then, on November 25, teams at NASAâ€™s Goddard Space Flight Center in Greenbelt, Maryland, joined the inner and outer portions of the Roman Space Telescope. With this milestone, NASA declared the observatory complete and on track for launch as soon as fall 2026. Read full article Comments

items.title: Senators count the shady ways data centers pass energy costs on to Americans
items.summary: Senators demand Big Tech pay upfront for data center spikes in electricity bills.
items.body: Senators launched a probe Tuesday demanding that tech companies explain exactly how they plan to prevent data center projects from increasing electricity bills in communities where prices are already skyrocketing. In letters to seven AI firms, Senators Elizabeth Warren (D-Mass.), Chris Van Hollen (D-Md.), and Richard Blumenthal (D-Conn.) cited a study estimating that â€œelectricity prices have increased by as much as 267 percent in the past five yearsâ€ in â€œareas located near significant data center activity.â€ Prices increase, senators noted, when utility companies build out extra infrastructure to meet data centersâ€™ energy demandsâ€”which can amount to one customer suddenly consuming as much power as an entire city. They also increase when demand for local power outweighs supply. In some cases, residents are blindsided by higher bills, not even realizing a data center project was approved, because tech companies seem intent on dodging backlash and frequently do not allow terms of deals to be publicly disclosed. Read full article Comments

items.title: Software leaks point to the first Apple Silicon â€œiMac Pro,â€ among other devices
items.summary: Resurrected high-end all-in-one could be a worthy successor to 2017's iMac Pro.
items.body: Apple doesnâ€™t like to talk about its upcoming products before itâ€™s ready, but sometimes the companyâ€™s software does the talking for it. So far this week weâ€™ve had a couple of software-related leaks that have outed products Apple is currently testingâ€”one a pre-release build of iOS 26 , and the other some leaked files from a kernel debug kit (both via MacRumors). Most of the new devices referenced in these leaks are straightforward updates to products that already exist: a new Apple TV, a HomePod mini 2, new AirTags and AirPods, an M4 iPad Air, a 12th-generation iPad to replace the current A16 version, next-generation iPhones (including the 17e, 18, and the rumored foldable model), a new Studio Display model, some new smart home products weâ€™ve already heard about elsewhere , and M5 updates for the MacBook Air, Mac mini, Mac Studio, and the other MacBook Pros. Thereâ€™s also yet another reference to the lower-cost MacBook that Apple is apparently planning to replace the M1 MacBook Air it still sells via Walmart for $599. For power users, though, the most interesting revelation might be that Apple is working on a higher-end Apple Silicon iMac powered by an M5 Max chip. The kernel debug â€¦

items.title: Reporter suggests Half-Life 3 will be a Steam Machine launch title
items.summary: "Everybody I've talked to are still adamant," even after previous rumors didn't pan out.
items.body: If you can take your mind way back to the beginning of 2025, you might remember a fresh wave of rumors suggesting that Half-Life 3 was finally reaching the final stages of production, and could be announced and/or released at any moment. Now, though, 2025 seems set to come to a close without any official news of a game fans have been waiting literal decades for. That doesnâ€™t necessarily mean a Half-Life 3 announcement and/or release isnâ€™t imminent, though. On the contrary, veteran journalist Mike Straw insisted on a recent Insider Gaming podcast that â€œeverybody Iâ€™ve talked to are still adamant [ Half-Life 3 ] is a game that will be a launch title with the Steam Machine.â€ Strawâ€”who has a long history of reporting gaming rumors from anonymous sources â€”said this Half-Life 3 information is â€œnot [from] these run-of-the-mill sources that havenâ€™t gotten me information before. â€¦ These arenâ€™t like random, one-off people.â€ And those sources are â€œstill adamant that the game is coming in the spring,â€ Straw added, noting that he was â€œspecifically told [that] spring 2026 [is the window] for the Steam Machine, for the Frame, for the Controller, [and] for Half-Life 3 .â€ Read full article Comments

items.body: Utah Gov. Spencer Cox believes his state needs more powerâ€”a lot more. By some estimates, Utah will require as much electricity in the next five years as it generated all last century to meet the demands of a growing population as well as chase data centers and AI developers to fuel its economy. To that end, Cox announced Operation Gigawatt last year, declaring the state would double energy production in the next decade. Although the announcement was short on details, Cox, a Republican, promised his administration would take an â€œany of the aboveâ€ approach, which aims to expand all sources of energy production. Despite that goal, the Utah Legislatureâ€™s Republican supermajority, with Coxâ€™s acquiescence, has taken a hard turn against solar powerâ€”which has been coming online faster than any other source in Utah and accounts for two-thirds of the new projects waiting to connect to the stateâ€™s power grid. Read full article Comments

items.title: 2026 Mercedes CLA first drive: Entry level doesnâ€™t mean basic
items.summary: Starting at $47,250, Mercedes' new electric sedan is quite compelling.
items.body: Mercedes-Benz provided flights from Washington to San Francisco and accommodation so Ars could drive the CLA. Ars does not accept paid editorial content. SAN FRANCISCOâ€”Automakers are starting to follow somewhat familiar paths as they continue their journeys to electrification. Electric vehicles are, at first, strange new tech, and usually look like it. Mercedes-Benzâ€™s EQS and EQE are good examplesâ€”with bodies that look like bars of soap worn down in the shower, they stood out. For early adopters and trailblazers that might be fine, but you need to sell cars to normal people if you want to survive, and that means making EVs more normal. Which is what Mercedes did with its newest one, the all-electric CLA. The normal looks belie the amount of new technology that Mercedes has packed into the CLA, though. The car sticks to the four-door coupe look that the company pioneered a couple of decades ago, but thereâ€™s a thoroughly modern electric powertrain connected to the wheels, run by four powerful networked computers. And yes, thereâ€™s AI. (For the pedants, â€œcoupeâ€ means cut down, not two-door, so the name is accurate.) The CLA is the first of a new series of Mercedes that will use the saâ€¦

items.title: 2025 is the second-hottest year since records began
items.summary: Mean temperatures this year approached 1.5Â°C above the preindustrial average, making it the second hottest year after 2024

items.title: Odd elements in supernova blast might have implications for alien life
items.summary: Some of the elements used by living systems are far more abundant in Cassiopeia A than we thought, hinting that some parts of our galaxy might be more suitable for life than others

items.title: How worried should you be about spending too much time on your phone?
items.summary: Screen time has been linked to all sorts of problems, from depression and obesity to poor sleep. But how worried should you really be? Jacob Aron sifts through the evidence

items.title: What the family drama of interbreeding polar and grizzly bears reveals
items.summary: A hybrid grolar bear saga is unfolding in the Arctic, and the tale of this strange family has much to tell us about nature on our changing planet

items.title: Extreme heat hampers childrenâ€™s early learning
items.summary: Children regularly exposed to temperatures over 30Â°C (86Â°F) have lower scores on literacy and numeracy tests at age 3 to 4, according to UNICEF data from six countries

items.title: Inside McLaren's season - the rules, values, incidents & relationships
items.summary: Intra-team title battles turn toxic far more often than not. Andrew Benson analyses how McLaren have maintained relative harmony between Lando Norris and Oscar Piastri.

items.title: Too busy to meditate? Microdosing mindfulness has big health benefits
items.summary: Small bursts of mindfulness practices lasting a minute or less can have unexpected benefits for those with busy lives - hereâ€™s how

items.title: Are we living in a simulation? This experiment could tell us
items.summary: The idea that we might be living in a simulated reality has worried us for centuries. Now physicists have found some tantalising clues â€“ and devised an experiment that might reveal the truth

items.title: Unseen film footage from the making of 'Do They Know Itâ€™s Christmas?'
items.summary: A documentary unearthing 75 minutes of rare footage from the day of recording

items.title: Comet 3I/ATLAS from beyond solar system carries key molecule for life
items.summary: Astronomers have discovered that 3I/ATLAS is carrying methanol and other chemicals that were probably important in the origin of life

items.title: Tattooing may trigger localised damage to the immune system
items.summary: There is relatively little information on the long-term health effects of tattooing, but a couple of recent studies suggest the art form might trigger prolonged inflammation

items.title: Hunter-gatherer groups are much less egalitarian than they seem
items.summary: There is a widespread belief that altruism and equality drive social behaviour in traditional hunter-gatherer societies, but the truth is more surprising and complex

items.title: Quantum experiment settles a century-old row between Einstein and Bohr
items.summary: Albert Einstein and Niels Bohr had an ongoing rivalry about the true nature of quantum mechanics, and came up with a thought experiment that could settle the matter. Now, that experiment has finally been performed for real

items.title: How Australian teens are planning to get around their social media ban
items.summary: From legal challenges to lesser-known apps, the teenagers of Australia are already preparing to push back against a law that will see under 16s banned from social media

items.title: England's AI World Cup masterplan - from perfecting penalties to powering players
items.summary: BBC Sport hears from inside the England setup about how artificial intelligence is powering plans for next summer's World Cup.

items.title: AI can influence voters' minds. What does that mean for democracy?
items.summary: Voters change their opinions after interacting with an AI chatbot â€“ but, encouragingly, it seems that AIs rely on facts to influence people

items.title: Why is AI making computers and games consoles more expensive?
items.summary: The AI industry consumes vast amounts of energy, fresh water and investor cash. Now it also needs memory chips - the same ones used in laptops, smartphones and games consoles

items.title: Volcano eruption may have led to the Black Death coming to Europe
items.summary: Climate data and historical accounts suggest that crop failures in the 1340s prompted Italian officials to import grain from eastern Europe, and this may have carried in the plague bacterium

items.title: Images reveal the astonishing complexity of the microscopic world
items.summary: From a dragonfly to marine organisms, photographer Michael Benson zoomed in with powerful scanning electron microscopes to take these extraordinary shots for his book Nanocosmos

items.title: Could the super-rich be cloning themselves? And why would they?
items.summary: Nearly three decades since the remarkable cloning of Dolly the sheep, it has all gone quiet on the human cloning front. Michael Le Page wonders what's happening behind the scenes

items.title: Tigers seem to be bouncing back in remote Sumatran jungle
items.summary: Camera traps in an area of the Leuser rainforest patrolled by NGOs spotted 17 tigers in 2023 and 18 Sumatran tigers in 2024, while surveys elsewhere on the island averaged seven

items.title: Incredible close-up of spider silk wins science photo prize
items.summary: Duelling prairie chickens, a snake-mimicking moth and a once-a-year sunrise at the South Pole feature in the best images from the Royal Society Publishing Photography Competition 2025

items.title: Human challenge trials have never been more popular
items.summary: The ethics of clinical trials that deliberately infect people with a disease aren't clear-cut â€“ but there's a strong case for doing more of them

items.title: Why do I feel lonely even when I'm surrounded by a festive crowd?
items.summary: Feeling alienated in others' company, or "existential isolation", can happen to us all. David Robson digs into the psychological literature for a solution for one reader

items.title: The two standout science-fiction films of 2025
items.summary: From Mickey 17 and M3gan 2.0 to a musical about the end of the world, this was an eclectic year for science-fiction films. Film columnist Simon Ings shares his two breakout hits

items.title: The four best science documentaries of 2025
items.summary: From animal rivals to Jane Goodall's last thoughts, enjoy 2025's best science documentaries, says our TV columnist Bethan Ackerley

items.title: Stop treating your pet like a fur baby â€“ you're damaging its health
items.summary: Pet owners' increasing tendency to see their animals as children rather than dogs or cats can have dire consequences. Owners, and veterinarians, should be wary, warns Eddie Clutton

items.title: The six best science-fiction shows of 2025
items.summary: What were the year's top sci-fi shows? Andor and Severance are still up there, but our TV columnist Bethan Ackerley also has some unexpected tips to share

items.title: Dogs may make us more caring and sociable by changing our microbiome
items.summary: We know that pets influence our microbiome, but scientists have now found that having a dog seems to change this ecosystem in a way that could boost our well-being

items.title: How deliberately giving people illnesses is supercharging medicine
items.summary: The covid-19 pandemic opened the door to once-controversial human challenge trials. Now, volunteers are willingly catching norovirus and influenza to reveal how our immune systems really fight back

items.title: Planned satellite launches could ruin Hubble Space Telescope images
items.summary: More than half a million satellites are planned to launch by the end of the 2030s, and simulations suggest they will have a severe impact on space-based astronomy

items.title: Forming moon may have taken three big impacts early in Earthâ€™s history
items.summary: Conventionally, the moon is thought to have formed during one big impact, but a three-impact model might make more sense

items.title: Ancient human artefacts found near caves in Arabian desert
items.summary: Today, the deserts of the Arabian peninsula are inhospitable â€“ but 100,000 years ago, the area was full of animals and ancient humans

items.title: Why quantum mechanics says the past isnâ€™t real
items.summary: The famous double-slit experiment brings into question the very nature of matter. Its cousin, the quantum eraser experiment, makes us question the very existence of time â€“ and how much we can manipulate it

items.title: Black hole entropy hints at a surprising truth about our universe
items.summary: Two clashing ideas about disorder inside black holes now point to the same strange conclusions, and it could reshape the foundations of how we think about space and time

items.title: Can viral relationship tests really tell you about your relationship?
items.summary: Is there any science to viral relationship tests like the bird test, the orange peel theory and the moon phase test? Emily Impett, a professor of psychological and brain sciences at the University of Toronto, has the answers

items.title: Asteroid Bennu carries all the ingredients for life as we know it
items.summary: We knew from prior analyses that a distant asteroid sampled in 2020 carried all but one of the molecules needed to kick-start life, and researchers have just found the missing ingredient: sugar

items.title: Coral reefs have fuelled severe global warming in Earth's past
items.summary: Over the past 250 million years, periods when coral reef growth has peaked have coincided with big rises in sea temperatures

items.title: We now have a greater understanding of how exercise slows cancer
items.summary: Tumour growth is reduced by exercise due to a shift in the bodyâ€™s metabolism that means muscle cells outcompete cancer cells in the race to get sugar to grow

items.title: A sinister, deadly brain protein could reveal the origins of all life
items.summary: We have long struggled to determine how the first living organisms on Earth came together. Now, surprising evidence hints that poorly understood prions may have been the vital missing ingredient
